 ADB  has  been  committed  to  MDGs  since  2002.  The  attainment  of 
MDGs  will  help  achieve  inclusive  economic  growth,  a  key  objective  of 
ADB’s  long-term  strategic  framework  2008–2020  (Strategy  2020), 
which encourages ADB member countries to promote greater access to 
opportunities  by  expanding  human  capacities,  especially  for  the 
disadvantaged,  through  investments  in  education,  health,  and  basic 
social  protections.  In  line  with  Strategy  2020,  the  PMDGP  focuses  on 
governance  of  health  service  delivery  and  management  of  public 
resources.  Moreover,  the  PMDGP  adopts  a  programmatic  modality, 
which  by  leveraging  policy  and  institutional  reforms  is  expected  to 
ensure  sustained  GoPb  focus  on  health  sector  needs  beyond  the 
medium term, unlike stand-alone project interventions. 

The  PMDGP  is  an  integral  part  of  the  Punjab  Government  Efficiency 
Improvement Program Cluster approved by ADB in December 2007.  

The  PMDGP  marks  a  major  priority  shift  by  the  Punjab  Health 
Department from quantity to quality of health care, from fragmented to 
consolidated health service, and from tertiary to primary and secondary 
health  care.  The  impact  of  the  PMDGP  is  the  attainment  of  MDGs 
relating  to  the  reduction  of  the  infant  mortality  rate  and  maternal 
mortality  ratio  in  Punjab  Province.  The  Program’s  outcome  will  be 
improved  access,  quality,  and  equity  of  health  services.  The  Program 
will  assist  the  GoPb  in  undertaking  health  sector  reforms  in  the

characterized  the  Pakistan  economy  since  early  2000s.  For  the  first  time  since  FY2003,  the 
economy  has  posted  a  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  rate  below  6%,  caused  by 
both  domestic  and  international  developments.  During  FY2008,  domestic  supply  shocks  and

11. 
Timely use of quality primary and secondary health care by the poor, especially women 
and children in rural areas, is the key to attaining the MDGs relating to the IMR and MMR. The 
Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  (PLGO)  has  made  the  district  governments  responsible 
for primary  and secondary health services, which  are the key to attaining MDGs,  whereas the 
provincial Health Department has retained responsibility for policy setting for the entire sector; 
performance  monitoring;  and  the  provision  of  tertiary  care  services,  medical  education,  and 
research and development. Punjab’s primary health service system consists of 293 rural health 
centers  (RHCs),  2,456  basic  health  units  (BHUs),  and  188  maternal  and  child  health  centers. 
For secondary health services, there are 35 district headquarter hospitals (DHQs) and 77 tehsil 
headquarter hospitals (THQs). Punjab has over 140,000 health department employees spread 
across its 35 districts.  

12. 
Realizing  that  health  MDGs  would  not  be  attained  without  wide-ranging  health  sector 
reforms, GoPb has developed a health sector reform framework as part of the ADB-supported 
PRMP. It has also designed a Health Sector Reform Program (HSRP), which has been under 
implementation with GoPb’s own financing since 2006.13 In parallel, GoPb has taken measures 
to strengthen district level social service delivery systems through the PDSSP. GoPb has also 
adopted minimum service delivery standards (MSDS) for health services through PDSSP.  

B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

13. 
In Punjab, the health system consists of two parallel streams. The budget-based public 
health  system  provides  health  care  to  any  user  of  a  public  facility,  with  negligible  official  user 
charges.  The  private  health  care  system  is  largely  unregulated  and  charges  fees  for  services. 
Qualified  private  providers  mainly  cater  to  urban  populations  who  can  afford  the  fees.  Public 
sector  spending  accounts  for  less  than  20%  of  total  expenditures,  with  privately  provided  and 
procured  health  care  dominating  the  sector.  Yet,  for  the  rural  poor,  public  health  facilities  are 
often the only choice for receiving qualified and affordable medical care.  

14. 
Despite the massive network of public primary and secondary health facilities, coverage 
of basic health services remains low (Appendix 4). The reasons for low coverage of basic health 
services  include  limited  availability  and  low  quality  of  services,  and  suboptimal  health-seeking 
behavior.  Public  primary  health  care  has  been  largely  underutilized  mainly  because  of  the 
absence  of  doctors,  unavailability  of  drugs,  and  unreliable  and  poor  quality  of  services.  The 
biggest obstacle for improving quality is the absence of doctors and paramedics, and the poor 
quality  of  their  training.  The  day-to-day  management  of  health  services  has  suffered  from 
inadequate  capacity,  challenges  in  recruiting  and  posting  motivated  doctors  and  other 
professionals in rural and remote areas, rigid administrative procedures, inefficient and lengthy 
procurement processes for drugs and medical supplies, and lack of performance monitoring to

Need for Implementing Service Delivery Standards 

17. 
The  demand  for,  and  spending  on,  private  health  care  is  higher  because  the  public 
perceive the quality of private health care to be better than that at public health facilities. Low 
quality, lack of standardized provision of health services within and across health facilities, lack 
of  adequate  human  resources,  and  lack  of  drugs  and  medical  supplies  have  been  the  main 
impediments resulting in the low utilization of BHUs and RHCs. The public either chooses to use 
unqualified health care providers or home treatment, or go to hospitals even for minor illnesses. 
This  has  resulted  in  delays  in  seeking  appropriate  health  care  when  needed  as  well  as 
overcrowded hospitals. 

18. 
Both  the  federal  and  provincial  governments  are  allowed  to  set  health  sector  policies.

The MSDS notified in Punjab in December 2007 have filled this crucial gap. They were 
developed  through  consultations  involving  provincial  and  district  health  officials  and  public

health  care,  and  the  required  physical  and  human  resource  requirements.  To  facilitate  the 
implementation  of  MSDS,  GoPb  has  also  developed  comprehensive  referral  guidelines, 
standard operating procedures (SOPs), and standard medical protocols (SMPs). MSDS, SOPs, 
and SMPs together have well-defined accountability parameters at each level of health care, for

21. 
The  lack  of  well-trained  human  resources  is  the  biggest  constraint  in  implementing 
MSDS. To implement the MNCH-related MSDS successfully, it is critical to have adequate and 
well-qualified  and  skilled  women  medical  officers  (WMOs),  midwives,  nurses,  female  health 
visitors, and paramedics. Currently, about 22% of the approved posts for various health workers 
at BHUs and RHCs in Punjab are vacant. Among the medical staff, the highest (32%) proportion 
of vacant posts is for the WMO. Similarly, 37% of the approved posts for nurses at BHUs and 
RHCs are currently vacant. At DHQs, almost one third of the approved posts of gynecologists 
and anesthetists are vacant. The situation is even worse at THQs, where 48% of the approved 
posts of gynecologists and 59% of anesthetists’ posts are vacant. 14 
 
22. 
To  implement  MNCH-related  MSDS  effectively,  about  14,000  new  posts  need  to  be 
approved  and  filled.  They  include  about  660  specialists  (primarily  gynecologists,  obstetricians, 
anesthetists,  and  pediatricians);  about  1,550  medical  officers  (including  WMOs);  about 
5,000 nurses;  3,000  each  of  lady  health  visitors  and  midwives;  and  1,000  paramedics.  The 
shortage  is  especially  pronounced  among  paramedics  and  nurses.  Against  this  requirement, 
Punjab  produces  about  1,400–1,600  nurses  and  350  lady  health  visitors per  year.  In  addition, 
39,000  nurses  have  been  registered  until  2006.  Therefore,  once  posts  are  approved,  a 
substantial part of them are expected to be filled in the next 2 years. For some posts, however, 
additional measures may be necessary for attracting health workers to the posts. For example, 
Punjab  produces  a  large  number  of  doctors—including  female  doctors—in  relation  to  nurses, 
but the availability of WMOs (particularly in rural areas) is a challenge as many female doctors 
leave  the  profession  or  opt  to  practice  in  urban  areas.  GoPb  has  introduced  incentives  for 
doctors posted at BHUs. As a result, their vacancies at BHUs have significantly reduced for the 
last 2 years.  
 
23. 
Apart  from  the  quantitative  challenge,  there  are  serious  quality  concerns  in  the  health 
profession.  Some  of  the  medical  training  institutions  in  Punjab  do  not  appear  to  apply  any 
stringent  quality  standards.  In  addition,  there  is  no  continuous  education  system  to  enable 
doctors to update their knowledge and skills regularly. Further, the quality of paramedics is not 
up to required standards. For instance, the entrance requirement for dispensers is only 10 years 
of  schooling.  Since  1947,  only  about  35,000  dispensers  have  been  qualified  out  of  1.2  million 
who  appeared  for  the  exam  after  a  year  of  training.  The  quality  of  training  offered  is  very  low 
mainly because of lack of qualified trainers. Consequently, the quality of the paramedics is low 
and they are ill-prepared to offer quality care.

Need for Improved Management of Health Service Delivery 

25.  Management  and  Performance  Monitoring.  One  of  the  lessons  from  the  PDSSP  is 
that district governments require substantial technical assistance (TA) to develop and manage a 
rational and strategic action plan. ODGHS,  which was responsible for delivering district health 
services before the 2001 devolution, is now responsible for providing TA to district governments 
and  monitoring  performance  of  health  services  in  districts.  The  structure  and  capacity  of  the 
office,  however,  has  not  been  adjusted  to  its  new  responsibilities;  consequently,  there  is  a 
serious  vacuum  of  monitoring  and  supervision.  The  office  still  has  10  senior  directors  and 
350 supporting  staff,  and  in  some  cases  continues  to  work  on  services  that  are  supposed  to 
have  been  devolved.  On  the  other  hand,  the  district  health  departments  are  left  to  assume 
responsibilities  for  primary  and  secondary  health  service  delivery,  without  the  Health 
Department’s technical support.  
 
26.  Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) cannot be effective in the absence of a comprehensive 
information  system.  There  is  no  consolidated  source  in  place  that  provides  reliable  and 
comprehensive health information on time to those managing health services. At the provincial 
level,  the  HSRP  has  its  own  effective  mechanism  of  collecting  information  through  M&E 
assistants whereas ODGHS collects routine information from health facilities through executive 
district  officers  (EDOs),  Health.  Federal  or  provincial  vertical  programs  and  donor-funded 
projects have their own mechanisms to collect information through their respective district and 
subdistrict  coordinators.  In  addition,  a  number  of  studies  and  community  surveys  are  being 
undertaken  by  various  stakeholders.  However,  the  collected  information  is  hardly  used  for 
improving health services, particularly at the local level.  
 
27. 
Recently  the  Health  Department  has  pilot  tested  a  comprehensive  district  health 
information  system  (DHIS),  which  can  generate  information  on  indicators  related  to  service 
delivery,  human  resources,  financial  management,  logistics,  capital  assets,  and  regulations. 
DHIS  is  gradually  becoming  operational  in  the  pilot  districts.  Districts’  capacity  is  the  major 
constraint in rapid expansion. The posts for a director at ODGHS for DHIS have only recently 
been  filled  and  district  DHIS  related  officers’  posts  have  not  yet  been  filled.  DHIS  will  be  an 
important  instrument  for  the  Health  Department  to  monitor  district  health  service  performance 
and adjust its strategies.

just for health service delivery but also for ensuring efficient use of public funds.

Under-Financing  at  the  National  Level.  Public  health  care  is  financed  through 
budgetary allocations from three different levels of government: federal, provincial, and district. 
Pakistan’s  public  health  care  has  been  persistently  underfinanced.  Its  total  health  care 
expenditure in 2004 was only 2.2% of GDP, more than 80% of which was private expenditure. 
Per capita government expenditure on health was only $9.4, against a benchmark of about $30 
recommended  by  the  World  Health  Organization  for  developing  countries.  It  also  compares 
unfavorably  with  neighboring  countries  such  as  Sri  Lanka  ($74.1),  Nepal  ($18.6),  Bangladesh 
($18.1), and India ($15.8).  

The increase in district governments’ spending responsibilities has not been matched by 
36. 
concurrent revenue autonomy necessary to fulfill this new role. District governments depend on 
the  provincial  fiscal  transfers  for  a  large  part  of  their  revenues  through  Provincial  Finance 
Commission  (PFC)  awards.  District  governments  typically  spend  less  than  $2  per  capita  on 
health  care,  severely  under-financing  primary  and  secondary  health  care.  This  has  led  to 
shortage  of  drugs  and  medical  supplies  across  health  facilities.  For  FY2003–FY2007,  total 
health sector expenditure accounted for 6%–13% of district governments’ total regular budget. 
The health sector’s share in district governments’ recurrent budget ranges from 7%–19%, and 
0%–7% in the development budget depending on the district. Salaries account for about 60% of 
total  health  expenditures.  The  HSRP  and  the  tied  grants  received  under  the  ADB-supported 
PDSSP are sometimes the sole sources of funding for health sector development  schemes in 
some districts. Under the PDSSP, conditional grants are being provided to district governments 
and  the  tehsil  municipal  administration  to  achieve  progress  toward  MDGs  related  to  poverty, 
gender, education, health, and water supply and sanitation. The grants are transferred as part of 
the PFC award. Seventy percent of the grant is transferred based on population and 30% based 
on  the  development  deprivation  index  calculated  based  on  the  Multiple  Indicators  Cluster 
Survey  data.  A  memorandum  of  understanding  (MOU)  between  GoPb  and  each  local 
government sets the rules and conditions of the grants. The MOU defines the specific eligibility 
criteria  and  access  criteria  each  local  government  has  to  meet  to  receive  the  grants.  It  also 
establishes  criteria  for  the  use  of  funds,  including  the  request  that  funds  be  kept  in  a  civil 
account  and  that  such  account  and  related  financial  statements  be  audited  annually  by  the 
District Audit Office of the Auditor General of Pakistan.

health in recent years. Still, in FY2007, GoPb’s total health care spending was PRs23.5 billion, 
or  $4.4  per  capita,  which  is  less  than  half  of  the  national  per  capita  spending.  Overall,  total

and facilities responsible for delivery of services. Weak financial reporting undermines resource 
allocation decisions at the time budget estimates are prepared or revised, and prevents rational 
scrutiny of resources utilized in service delivery.

43.  Weak  Fiduciary  Environment.  An  organization’s  internal control  system  is  defined  as 
the whole network of systems established to provide reasonable assurance that objectives will 
be  achieved  in  an  efficient  and  economic  manner;  and  that  policies,  procedures,  laws,  and 
regulations  are  complied  with.  A  well-structured  and  executed  internal  control  system  ensures 
the integrity and reliability of information, accounts, and data; and provides assurance that the 
institutions’ assets and interests are protected from losses. The role of internal audit, in turn, is 
based on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. Any audit

or are inadequate.

the district account officer at the district level and Accountant General’s Office at the provincial

the  rules  are  widely  understood,  in  some  cases  they  may  be  excessive,  cause  unnecessary

Continuation  of  the  present  budget-supported  public  health  provisions  may  be  an  option,  if 
adjusted to emerging issues; clearly, this will be inadequate. As the GoPb successfully improves 
public  health  services,  not  only  the  relative  poor,  but  also  wealthier  people,  may  start  using

care  may  disproportionately  subsidize  wealthier  people,  without  a  progressive  tax  scheme  in 
place,  and  lead  to  a  distorted  and  highly  unsustainable  system.  To  develop  an  equitable  and 
sustainable  health  financing  system,  an  in-depth  assessment,  especially  of  out-of-pocket 
expenditure,  is  required.  Until  a  holistic  equitable  health  financing  system  is  developed, 
immediate safety net measures for reducing the poor’s health expenditure burden are needed.

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

Improved  Access  and  Quality  of  Primary  and  Secondary  Health  Services.  By 
103. 
helping Punjab attain the health MDGs, the proposed Program will have potentially helped the 
province save at least 11,000 women’s lives and 235,000 infants’ lives by 2015 compared to the 
scenario without program support, assuming that the two health MDGs are fully met within that 
time frame. By helping all 35 district governments endorse and implement MSDS, the Program 
will ensure that minimum acceptable levels of service delivery standards are followed across the 
entire  province.  The  adoption  of  guidelines  for  MSDS  implementation  and  the  requirement  for 
district  governments  to  develop  a  time-bound  and  fully-costed  implementation  plan  will  help 
minimize slippages in the introduction of the minimum standards. Sufficient and capable human 
resources are an essential determinant of service quality. The proposed Program will improve 
the  capacity  of  the  Health  Department  and  district  governments  to  plan  their  human  resource 
needs, and more importantly will support continued education of medical staff. Finally, progress 
toward  introduction  of  a  quality  assurance  mechanism  for  private  health  care  providers  will 
ensure a safe and uniform standard of services across the province. By ensuring primary and 
secondary health services to meet MSDS, the Program is expected to have a positive impact on 
MDG6 on HIV/AIDS. MSDS includes HIV preventive measures.  

104.  Poverty  Reduction.  Poor  people  have  the  worst  health  outcomes.  They  are  pushed 
further  into  poverty  because  of  ill  health,  resulting  in  lower  productivity  or  loss  of  daily  wages, 
and a burden of high health care expenditures. Although public health care is in principle free, 
patients  often  have  to  pay  substantial  amounts  for  health  care  because  of  missing  drugs  and 
supplies at public health facilities. The cost of care at private facilities is even more expensive. 
By making quality and affordable care available at public facilities through a targeted program, 
and the development of an equitable health financing system, the proposed Program will reduce 
the  health  care  expenditure  burden  and  the  risks  of  falling  seriously  ill  by  giving  timely 
interventions.  By  ensuring  increased  allocations  to  primary  and  secondary  health  care,  and 
distributing  the  conditional  grants  among  districts  through  a  formula  that  takes  into  account 
poverty incidence, the Program will make public finances more pro-poor. The summary poverty 
reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 12. 

105. 
Improved Management of Health Services. Timely availability of drugs and medicines 
in all health facilities is an essential aspect of health service delivery. The Program will support 
streamlining  of  the  drug  procurement  process  and  will  help  the  Government  institutionalize 
alternative mechanisms for service delivery by building on lessons from experience.  

106.  Economic  Impact.  Improved  public  financial  management  in  the  health  sector  and 
better  strategic  planning  skills  in  the  Health  Department  will  contribute  to  increased  value  for 
money  of  public  spending.  Provision  of  conditional  grants  to  district  governments  for  MDG-
related  interventions  will  ease  district  governments’  resource  constraints  while  ensuring  that 
essential service delivery priorities are protected from expenditure cuts. The increased access 
and quality of public health services will also have a direct poverty-reducing impact by lowering 
the burden of health expenditures on the poor.  

107.

Strengthening  of  the  strategy  and  policy  unit  within  the  Health  Department  will  ensure  that 
policies  and  strategies  are  properly  defined,  corresponding  actions  planned,  and  resources 
allocated  accordingly.  Creation  of  the  FMC  and  related  capacity-building  interventions  will

B. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures  

108.  Political  Risks. There is strong commitment at both political and bureaucratic levels in 
Punjab to improving the living standards of the poor. To this purpose, GoPb has accorded high 
priority to investments in social sectors, particularly health and education. The FY2009 recurrent 
and  development  budget  allocations  to  the  health  sector  have  substantially  increased  (+53% 
recurrent  and  +38%  development).  Although  commitment  to  the  broad  direction  of  reforms  is 
ensured, the future of the local government system under the new political setup may be at risk 
as  provincial  governments  across  Pakistan  are  exploring  options  to  revisit  intra-provincial 
administrative and fiscal relationships within the current local government system. While a total 
reversal of the 2001 PLGO is unlikely, changes in the current distribution of power and authority 
across levels of government may occur. The flexibility built into the single tranche operations is 
well-suited  to  addressing  the  uncertainty  surrounding  the  local  government  setup,  and  reform 
actions  may  be  adjusted  under  subprogram  2.  However,  if  the  change  in  the  PLGO  leads  to 
separation of primary and secondary health services financing and administrative management, 
the negative effect of the separation (i.e., further fragmentation of the health services) would be 
very difficult to contain. ADB should dialogue closely with GoPb to avoid such fragmentation.  

109.  Governance  Risks. There are several governance risks in the areas of public financial 
management,  expenditure  planning  and  control,  procurement,  and  corruption.  As  a  policy  and 
institutional reform program, the PMDGP deliberately and explicitly puts governance and public 
expenditure management issues at the center of the reform effort. Reforms proposed under the 
PMDGP  will  positively  affect  the  current  institutional  setup  in  the  health  sector  and  address 
these  governance  risks.  The  change  in  public  financial  management  practices  and  the 
emphasis on results-based allocation of resources is likely to encounter resistance from middle-
management  officials  who  have  vested  interests  in  perpetuating  the  situation.  The  strong 
commitment  to  reform  at  the  highest  political  and  bureaucratic  level  within  the  Health 
Department will help mitigate this risk. In addition, internal and external performance M&E, and 
publicizing  the  performance  are  expected  to  change  the  situation  gradually.  The  PMDGP  has 
built-in third-party assessments, including a citizen satisfaction survey, as policy conditions.  

C. 

Implementation Risks  

110.  Capacity Risks. The success of the PMDGP is premised on the existence of a cadre of 
qualified  and  committed  health  professionals  at  all  levels,  and  assumes  that  the  proposed 
incentive structures ensure the retention of health professionals, particularly those posted to the 
BHUs. There are risks that the required number of health professionals may not be immediately 
available  for  the  public  sector.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  GoPb  has  introduced  monetary  and 
nonmonetary  incentives  for  doctors  posted  at  BHUs,  which  have  resulted  in  a  significant 
reduction of vacancies. In addition, the measures of the PMDGP will cascade over time, starting 
with lower levels and gradually moving up to doctors. At the lower levels, the required number of 
female  health  visitors,  for  instance,  can  be  mobilized  in  a  relatively  short  period.  The  Health

111.  External  and  Macroeconomic  Risks.  The  recent  upsurge  in  international  commodity

SUMMARY PUNJAB HEALTH SECTOR ANALYSIS  

A. 

Situation of Health Indicators and Services 

The  Government  is  a  signatory  to  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs),  and  is 
1. 
fully committed to achieving them. However, progress toward achieving the MDGs in Pakistan is 
far from satisfactory. While there had been claims of poverty reduction, economic growth, and 
improvement  in  gross  domestic  product  (real  growth  rate1 rose  from  4.5%  in  2003  to  6.6%  in 
2007), no corresponding impact is visible on reducing maternal and child mortality. For example, 
the infant mortality rate (IMR) was 77 per 1,000 live births in 2000-2001 and 78 per 1,000 live 
births  in  2006–2007.  Pakistan’s  IMR  and  maternal  mortality  ratio  (MMR)  are  the  highest  in 
South Asia, population growth rate is the highest, and contraceptive availability the lowest. High 
population  growth  will  increase  pressure  on  the  already  weak  public  health  service  delivery 
system.  

2. 
As  Pakistan,  including  Punjab,  is  going  through  an  epidemiological  and  demographic 
transition, it is still facing a challenge of burden of pre-transitional communicable diseases, while 
the  prevalence  of  noncommunicable  and  chronic  illnesses  is  emerging  as  an  additional 
challenge for the already compromised health service delivery system. Coupled with prevailing 
illiteracy,  poverty,  and  low  status  of  women  in  society,  this  is  hampering  progress  toward 
achieving  the  MDGs  related  to  maternal,  neonatal  and  child  health  (MNCH).  Development 
efforts are further threatened because of political instability, extremism, and violence. 

3. 
Punjab health sector analysis shows that it is unlikely to achieve the MDGs unless the 
health  sector  is  effectively  reformed  to  make  good  quality  MNCH  services  accessible  to  the 
masses in Punjab. To bridge urban–rural inequity in coverage, more allocation will be required 
for  services  in  rural  areas  along  with  enhanced  efficiency  and  institutional  capacity  to  deliver 
good quality services. Furthermore, to achieve the MDG related to MMR (MDG5), a significant 
policy shift will be required to encourage institutional delivery to ensure that all required care can 
be offered including emergency obstetric care. 

1.

4. 
Child  Mortality  (MDG4).  In  Punjab,  the  under-five  mortality  rate  is  recorded  to  be 
112 per  1,000  live  births  (2003–2004).  There  is  significant  regional  disparity,  with  a  lower  rate 
(75  per  1,000  live  births)  in  major  urban  cities  and  a  higher  rate  (119  per  1,000  live  births)  in 
rural  Punjab—against  the  MDG  target  of  52  per  1,000  live births  by  2015.  The  IMR  in  Punjab 
was  115  in  1996–1997  and  has  been  reduced  to  77  per  1,000  live  births  in  2003–2004.2 It  is 
much higher in rural areas (82 per 1,000 live births) than major urban cities (55 per 1,000 live 
births).  Districts  located  in  northern  Punjab  close  to  the  provincial  capital  report  lower  IMR 
compared to districts in the south. The significant urban–rural disparity shows inequity in service 
distribution and access to basic health services in Punjab.  

5.

neonatal period caused by sepsis, asphyxia, preterm births, and neonatal tetanus.3 The causes

1. 

Public Financial Management in Theory  

32. 
The  budget,  as  a  management  tool  for  economic  and  fiscal  planning,  is  the 
communication  of  a  plan  for  a  given  period  expressed  in  financial  terms,  and  is  a  means  of 
controlling and monitoring the use of funds. Effective planning of programs and activities should 
precede  budget  preparation  so  that  the  main  policy  priorities  of  government  can  be  translated 
into  manageable  components  and  subsequently  costed  to  determine  affordability.  Budget 
preparation should then follow at the end of this process.  
 
Effective budget execution requires on the one hand that spending departments receive 
33. 
reliable information on available funds within which they can commit expenditure. This may be 
undermined by poor access to budget during the year and may lead to a downward revision of 
allocations in the revised budget estimates. On the other hand, basic management accounting 
practices throughout the year should enable management to analyze underperforming activities 
and  take  corrective  action  accordingly.  This  relies  on  the  preparation  of  systematic  financial 
reports,  and  constant  checking  and  verification  of  the  bookkeeping  and  recording  practices  of 
budget.  Important  reconciliations  should  be  undertaken  on  a  regular  (daily,  weekly,  monthly) 
basis  to  ensure  accuracy  in  recording,  reliability  in  reporting,  and  control  to  ensure  that 
adequate checks and balances exist at key points in the system.  
 
34. 
The  quality  of  the  internal  control  systems  within  an  organization  affects  the  fiduciary 
environment,  hence  the  efficiency  of  public  spending.  Organizations  and  their  systems  are 
susceptible  to  weaknesses  and  risks,  resulting  in  the  possibility  of  poor  performance,  error 
and/or  abuse.  Senior  management,  therefore,  introduces  and  maintains  control  procedures  to 
ensure that organizational objectives are achieved and public standards are met. Internal audit, 
in turn, relies on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. The 
internal  audit  department  of  any  organization  is  an  integral  part  of  the  management  of  that 
organization. It can be defined as an independent, objective assurance and consulting activity 
designed  to  add  value  and  improve  an  organization’s  operations.  It  helps  an  organization 
accomplish  its  objectives  by  bringing  a  systematic,  disciplined  approach  to  evaluate  and 
improve the effectiveness of risk management, control, and governance processes. 
 
35. 
Unlike  internal  auditors,  external  auditors  are  independent  of  the  organization,  and 
provide  an  annual  opinion  on  the  financial  statements.  The  work  of  the  internal  and  external 
auditors should be coordinated for optimal effectiveness and efficiency. The primary mission of 
the  external  auditors  is  to  provide  an  independent  opinion  on  the  organization’s  financial 
statements  annually.  Their  approach  is  historical  in  nature,  as  they  assess  whether  the 
statements conform to generally accepted accounting principles, whether they fairly present the 
financial  position  of  the  organization,  whether  the  results  of  operations  for  a  given  period  are 
accurately represented, and whether the financial statements have been materially affected.

International  accounting  standards  dictate  that  any  organization  should  have  effective 
internal  audit.  The  internal  audit  function  is  an  integral  part  of  the  organization’s  management 
and it is based on the presence of an adequate, effective, and reliable set of internal controls. 
The findings and recommendations included in a standard internal audit report are reported to 
the  management  of  the  organization,  which  should  then  act  upon  these  recommendations. 
Subsequent  internal  audits  would  begin  with  previous  recommendations  and  whether  or  not 
management  has  acted  in  response.  Internal  audit  work  can,  and  often  is,  relied  upon  by 
external  auditors  to  help  target  the  time-limited  external  audit  to  areas  of  greatest  control 
weakness and to avoid duplication. 

In the health sector and in Punjab in general, the internal audit function is not effective.

and the absence of any training for the audit team are symptoms of the poor effectiveness of the

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Pakistan’s health indicators are the worst among South Asian countries. For instance, Pakistan’s infant mortality rate 
(IMR) is 78 compared to 57 in India and 46 in Nepal. Poor people have the worst health outcomes. They are pushed 
further into poverty because of ill health, resulting in lower productivity or loss of daily wages, and the burden of health 
care  expenditure.  Pakistan  rightly  recognizes  the  importance  of  improving  health  outcomes  (i.e.,  health  sector 
investments) as an important part of the Government’s poverty alleviation plan (Pakistan’s national health policy 2001).  
 
Pakistan,  especially  Punjab,  has  demonstrated  strong  commitment  to  achieving  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs), and actively monitoring the MDG indicators. The health care budget has increased substantially in the last few 
years. Despite these efforts, Punjab is unlikely to achieve the MDG targets for reduction of the maternal mortality ratio 
(MMR) and IMR without extra efforts and reforms in health service delivery, while it may achieve all other MDGs. 
 
The Punjab Millennium Development Goals Program intends to improve health services delivery by improving quality 
and standards of health care, increasing public health financing, improving the efficiency of public health financing, and 
institutional  management  of  health  service  delivery.  The  country  partnership  strategy  2007–2011,  which  is  being 
finalized, includes support for reforms to address governance and institutional bottlenecks leading to improved delivery 
of inclusive social services.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: TI-M 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The  majority  of  maternal  and  infant  deaths  in  Punjab  are  preventable  if  women  and  children  have  timely  access  to 
quality preventive, primary, and secondary  health care. Access is limited or delayed because health services are not 
physically available in their neighborhood, doctors and/medicines are not available, or services are unaffordable. Even 
if health care services are available, their quality is not always optimal. Punjab’s health service delivery system needs 
quantitative and qualitative improvements, and measures to reduce the burden of health care expenditure on the poor.  
 
Private  practitioners  are  prevalent,  but  in  rural  areas  they  are  often  quacks  and  unskilled  birth  attendants.  Qualified 
private  health  care  is  more  expensive  than  public  health  care.  Thus,  it  is  essential  to  improve  public  primary  and 
secondary health care, if Punjab is to reduce the IMR and MMR among the poor.  
 
The  poor  quality  of  public  primary  and  secondary  health  is  mainly  due  to  historical  under-financing  of  health  care  in 
Pakistan.  Pakistan’s  per  capita  public  health  expenditure  is  the  lowest  in  South  Asia.  It  spends  only  about  $9  per 
person,  against  the  $30–$40  recommended  by  the  World  Health  Organization  (WHO)  for  developing  countries.  In 
addition, the limited resources have not been utilized cost-effectively. Until 2 years ago, the majority of the health care 
budget of the government of Punjab went to tertiary health care, which mainly serves the urban population and whose 
benefits are known to be regressively distributed.  
 
2. Design Features 
 

The Program is aimed at improving maternal, neonatal, and child (MNCH) services for rural areas, where 
social  indicators are  worse than those urban areas. Availability of health  services is  a  major problem in 
rural areas.
